what: How to use the volkeR package?
title: Introduction
text: First, load package, set plot theme get data.
code: # Load the package library(volker)  # Set the basic plot theme theme_set(theme_vlkr())  # Load an example dataset ds from the package ds <- volker::chatgpt

what: How to generate tables and plots?
title: Introduction
text: Decide whether data categorical metric choose appropriate function: report_counts() shows frequency tables generates simple stacked bar charts. report_metrics() creates tables distribution parameters, visualises distributions density plots, box plots scatter plots. Report functions, hood, call functions generate plots, tables calculate effects. need one outputs, can call functions directly: tab_counts(), plot_counts() effect_counts() categorical data. tab_metrics(), plot_metrics() effect_metrics() metric data. functions expect dataset first parameter. second third parameters await column selections. column selections determine whether analyse single variables, item lists compare correlate multiple variables. Try following examples!

title: Introduction
text: can use sorts tidyverse style selections: single column, list columns patterns starts_with(), ends_with(), contains() matches().
code: # A single variable report_counts(ds, use_private) # A list of variables report_counts(ds, c(use_private, use_work)) # Variables matched by a pattern report_counts(ds, starts_with("use_"))

title: Introduction
text: Provide grouping column third parameter compare different groups. metric variables, can compare mean values. default, crossing variable treated categorical. can change behavior using metric-parameter calculate correlations: ci parameter, possible, adds confidence intervals outputs. Conduct statistical tests effect-parameter. See function help (F1 key) learn options. example, can use prop parameter grow bars 100%. numbers parameter prints frequencies percentages onto bars.
code: report_counts(ds, adopter, sd_gender) report_metrics(ds, sd_age, sd_gender) report_metrics(ds, sd_age, use_work, metric = TRUE) ds |>    filter(sd_gender != "diverse") |>    report_metrics(sd_age, sd_gender, ci = TRUE) ds |>    filter(sd_gender != "diverse") |>    report_counts(adopter, sd_gender, effect = TRUE) ds |>    filter(sd_gender != "diverse") |>    report_counts(adopter, sd_gender, prop="rows", numbers= "n")

code: codebook(ds) #> # A tibble: 97 × 6 #>    item_name     item_group item_class item_label         value_name value_label #>    <chr>         <chr>      <chr>      <chr>              <chr>      <chr>       #>  1 case          case       numeric    case               NA         NA          #>  2 sd_age        sd         numeric    Age                NA         NA          #>  3 cg_activities cg         character  Activities with C… NA         NA          #>  4 cg_act_write  cg         character  cg_act_write       NA         NA          #>  5 cg_act_test   cg         character  cg_act_test        NA         NA          #>  6 cg_act_search cg         character  cg_act_search      NA         NA          #>  7 adopter       adopter    factor     Innovator type     I try new… I try new … #>  8 adopter       adopter    factor     Innovator type     I try new… I try new … #>  9 adopter       adopter    factor     Innovator type     I wait un… I wait unt… #> 10 adopter       adopter    factor     Innovator type     I only us… I only use… #> # ℹ 87 more rows ds %>%   labs_apply(     items = list(       "cg_adoption_advantage_01" = "General advantages",       "cg_adoption_advantage_02" = "Financial advantages",       "cg_adoption_advantage_03" = "Work-related advantages",       "cg_adoption_advantage_04" = "More fun"     )   ) %>%    report_metrics(starts_with("cg_adoption_advantage_")) ds %>%   labs_apply(     cols = starts_with("cg_adoption"),       values = list(       "1" = "Strongly disagree",       "2" = "Disagree",       "3" = "Neutral",       "4" = "Agree",       "5" = "Strongly agree"     )    ) %>%    report_metrics(starts_with("cg_adoption")) library(readxl) library(writexl)  # Save codebook to a file codes <- codebook(ds) write_xlsx(codes,"codebook.xlsx")  # Load and apply a codebook from a file codes <- read_xlsx("codebook_revised.xlsx") ds <- labs_apply(ds, codes) ds %>%   labs_store() %>%   mutate(sd_age = 2024 - sd_age) %>%    labs_restore() %>%       report_metrics(sd_age)

title: Introduction
text: easiest way conduct factor analysis cluster analyses use respective parameters report_metrics() function. Currently, cluster analysis performed using kmeans factor analysis principal component analysis. Setting parameters true, automatically generates scree plots selects number factors clusters. Alternatively, can explicitly specify numbers. Add factor cluster analysis results original data want work results, use add_factors() add_clusters() respectively. factor analysis, new columns prefixed “fct_” created store factor loadings based specified number factors. clustering, additional column prefixed “cls_” added assigns observation cluster number. added factor cluster columns data set, can use report functions: explicitly adding factor cluster columns, can inspect analysis results using factor_tab(), factor_plot() cluster_tab(), cluster_plot(). Automatically determine number factors clusters automatically determine optimal number factors clusters based diagnostics, set k = NULL.
code: ds |>    report_metrics(starts_with("cg_adoption"), factors = TRUE, clusters = TRUE) ds |>    add_factors(starts_with("cg_adoption"), k = 3) |>    select(starts_with("fct_")) ds |>    add_factors(starts_with("cg_adoption"), k = 3)  |>   report_metrics(fct_cg_adoption_1, fct_cg_adoption_2, metric = TRUE) ds |>   add_clusters(starts_with("cg_adoption"), k = 3) |>   report_counts(sd_gender, cls_cg_adoption, prop = "cols") ds |>    add_factors(starts_with("cg_adoption"), k = 3)  |>   factor_tab(starts_with("fct_")) ds |>    add_factors(starts_with("cg_adoption"), k = NULL) |>   factor_tab(starts_with("fct_cg_adoption"))

what: Modeling: Regression and Analysis of Variance
title: Introduction
text: Modeling statistical sense predicting outcome (dependent variable) one multiple predictors (independent variables). report_metrics() function calculates linear model model parameter TRUE. provide variables following parameters: Dependent metric variable: first parameter dataset (cols parameter). Independent categorical variables: tidy column selection second parameter (cross parameter). Independent metric variables: tidy column selection third parameter (metric parameter. Interaction effects: interactions-parameter vector multiplication terms (e.g. interactions = c(sd_age * sd_gender)) Four selected diagnostic plots generated diagnostics-parameter TRUE: Residual vs. fitted: Residuals evenly distributed vertically. Horizontally, follow straight line. Otherwise indicator heteroscedasticity, non-linearity auto-correlationb. Scale-location plot: Points evenly distributed, without pattern, residual plot. Q-Q-Plot fitted values: dots located straight line. Otherweise, may indicate non-linearity residuals normally distributed. Cooks’ distance plot: High values indicate single cases influence model disproportionally. Rule thumb: Cook’s distance > 1 problem. work predicted values, use add_model() instead report function. add new variable prefixed prd_ holding target scores. two functions get regression table plot new column: default, p values adjusted number tests controlling false discovery rate (fdr). Set adjust-parameter FALSE disabling p correction.
code: ds |>  filter(sd_gender != "diverse") |>  report_metrics(    use_work,     cross = c(sd_gender, adopter),     metric = sd_age,    model = TRUE,    diagnostics = TRUE  ) ds <- ds |>    add_model(    use_work,    categorical = c(sd_gender, adopter),     metric = sd_age  )  report_metrics(ds, use_work, prd_use_work, metric = T) model_tab(ds, prd_use_work) model_plot(ds, prd_use_work)

title: Introduction
text: content analysis, reliability usually checked coding cases different persons calculating overlap. calculate reliability scores, prepare one data frame person: column names different data frames identical. Codings must either binary (TRUE/FALSE) contain fixed number values “sports”, “politics”, “weather”. Add column holding initials name coder. One column must contain unique IDs case, e.g. running case number. Next, row bind data frames. columns coder ID make sure coding uniquely identified can related cases coders. final data, example, looks like: Calculating reliability straight forward report_counts(): Provide data first parameter. Add column codings (selection multiple columns, e.g. using starts_with()) second parameter. Set third parameter column name coder names initials. Set ids-parameter column contains case IDs case numbers (tells volker-package cases belong together). Set agree-parameter “reliability” request reliability scores. Example: Alternatively, interested scores, plot, get using agree_tab. Hint: may abbreviate reliability value. , can request classification performance indicators (accuracy, precision, recall, F1) function setting method “classification” (may abbreviated). Use option compare manual codings automated codings (classifiers, large language models). default, get macro statistics (average precision, recall f1 categories). Give multiple values column, may focus one category get micro statistics:
code: data_coded <-  bind_rows(   data_coder1,   data_coder2 ) report_counts(data_coded, starts_with("topic_"), coder, ids = case, prop="cols", agree = "reliability") agree_tab(data_coded, starts_with("topic_"), coder, ids = case, method="reli") agree_tab(starts_with("topic_"), coder, ids = case, method = "class", category = "catcontent")

title: Introduction
text: Cases missing values, default, omitted methods. Thus, calculations based cases complete values selected columns. Furthermore, function first cleans values: Residual levels defined VLKR_NA_LEVELS constant recoded missing values (“[NA] nicht beantwortet”, “[NA] keine Angabe”, “[answer]” “keine Angabe”). Residual numeric values defined VLKR_NA_NUMBERS constant recoded missing values (-9, -2, -1). output always contains information many cases removed due missing values. three options treat missings: Disable recoding setting clean-parameter functions FALSE. Override values VLKR_NA_LEVELS VLKR_NA_NUMBERS calls options(vlkr.na.levels=c("answered")) options(vlkr.na.numbers=c(-2,-9)). set value FALSE, values recoded. analysing items, use pairwise complete data calling options(vlkr.na.omit=FALSE) (maximal information items).
code: print(volker:::VLKR_NA_LEVELS) #> [1] "[NA] nicht beantwortet" "[NA] keine Angabe"      "[no answer]"            #> [4] "keine Angabe"  print(volker:::VLKR_NA_NUMBERS) #> [1] -9 -2 -1

Report functions call subsidiary tab, plot effect functions, turn call functions specifically designed provided column selection. Open package help see, specific functions report functions redirected. Console markdown output pimped specific print- knit-functions. make work, cleaned data, produced plots, tables markdown snippets gain new classes (vlkr_df, vlkr_plt, vlkr_tbl, vlkr_list, vlkr_rprt). volker-package makes use common tidyverse functions. title: High-Level Functions for Tabulating, Charting and Reporting Survey Data
text: volkeR package made creating quick easy overviews datasets. handles standard cases handful functions. Basically select one following functions throw data : Categorical variables: report_counts() Metric variables: report_metrics() report functions combine tables, plots , optionally, effect size calculations. request one outputs, directly use respective function: Charts: plot_metrics() plot_counts() Tables: tab_metrics() tab_counts() Effects: effect_metrics() effect_counts() one best? depends objective: Table plot? plot quick capture, data table better calculations. Functions tables start tab, functions plots plot. doubt, create report-functions. Categorical metric variables? Categories can counted, metric variables distribution parameters mean standard deviation calculated. Functions categorical variables contain counts name, metric metrics. Individual, grouped correlated? Groups can compared (e.g., average age gender) cross-tabulated (e.g. combinations education level gender) providing grouping column third parameter table, plot report functions. calculate correlations show scatter plots, provide metric column set metric-Paramter TRUE. effect-functions calculate effect sizes statistical tests group comparisons correlations. One variable item batteries?. Item batteries often used surveys. item results single variable, variables measured scale (e.g. 1 = 5 = fully applies). summarise multiple items send column selection functions using tidyselect mechanisms starts_with(). Markdown data frame? table functions return data frames can processed . tables print function, output functions can used directly Markdown documents display neatly formatted tables plots. report-functions create tidy interactive tabsheets switch plots, tables, indexes.

title: High-Level Functions for Tabulating, Charting and Reporting Survey Data
text: functions take data frame first argument, followed column selection, optionally grouping column. Reproduce examples : One metric variable: report_metrics(data, sd_age) One categorical variable: report_counts(data, sd_gender) Grouped metric variable: report_metrics(data, sd_age, sd_gender) Grouped categorical variable: report_counts(data, adopter, sd_gender) Multiple metric variables: report_metrics(data, starts_with("cg_adoption")) Multiple categorical variables: report_counts(data, starts_with("cg_adoption")) column selections determine type output generated. second parameter (dataset), can either provide single column selection multiple items. compare groups, provide additional categorical column third parameter. calculate correlations, provide metric column third parameter set metric parameter TRUE. Note: column combinations implemented yet.

what: Modeling: Regression and Analysis of Variance
title: High-Level Functions for Tabulating, Charting and Reporting Survey Data
text: Modeling statistical sense predicting outcome (dependent variable) one multiple predictors (independent variables). report_metrics() function calculates linear model model parameter set TRUE. provide variables following parameters: Dependent metric variable: first parameter (single column). Independent categorical variables: second parameter (tidy column selection). Independent metric variables: metric parameter (tidy column selection). Interaction effects: interactions parameter vector multiplication terms (e.g. c(sd_age * sd_gender)). Four selected diagnostic plots generated diagnostics parameter set TRUE: Residual vs. fitted: Residuals evenly distributed vertically. Horizontally, follow straight line. Otherwise indicator heteroscedasticity, non-linearity, autocorrelation. Scale-location plot: Points evenly distributed without visible pattern, similar residual plot. Q-Q-Plot fitted values: points lie along straight line. Deviations may suggest non-linearity residuals normally distributed. Cook’s distance plot: High values indicate single cases influence model disproportionately. Rule thumb: Cook’s distance > 1 problem. work predicted values, use add_model() instead report function. add new variable prefixes prd_, holding target scores. two functions get regression table plot new column: default, p-values adjusted number tests controlling false discovery rate (fdr). Set adjust parameter FALSE disable p-value correction.
code: ds |>  filter(sd_gender != "diverse") |>  report_metrics(    use_work,     cross = c(sd_gender, adopter),     metric = sd_age,    model = TRUE, diagnostics = TRUE  ) ds <- ds |> add_model(    use_work,    categorical = c(sd_gender, adopter),     metric = sd_age  )  report_metrics(ds, use_work, prd_use_work, metric = T) model_tab(ds, prd_use_work) model_plot(ds, prd_use_work)

text: content analysis, reliability usually checked coding cases different persons calculating overlap. calculate reliability scores, prepare one data frame person: column names different data frames identical. Codings must either binary (TRUE/FALSE) contain fixed number values “sports”, “politics”, “weather”. Add column holding initials name coder. One column must contain unique IDs case (e.g., running case number). Next, row-bind data frames. coder ID columns ensure coding can uniquely matched coder case. final data, example, looks like: Calculating reliability straightforward report_counts(): Provide data first parameter. Add column codings (selection multiple columns, e.g. using starts_with()) second parameter. Set third parameter column name coder names initials. Set ids parameter column contains case IDs case numbers (tells volker-package cases belong together). Set agree parameter “reliability” request reliability scores. Example: interested scores (without plot), use agree_tab. Tip: may abbreviate method name (e.g., “reli” instead “reliability”). can also request classification performance indicators (accuracy, precision, recall, F1) function setting method parameter “classification” (may abbreviated). Use option comparing manual codings automated codings (e.g., classifiers large language models). default, get macro statistics (average precision, recall f1 across categories). multiple values column, can focus one category get micro statistics:
code: data_coded <- bind_rows(   data_coder1,   data_coder2 ) report_counts(data_coded, starts_with("topic_"), coder, ids = case, prop = "cols", agree = "reliability") agree_tab(data_coded, starts_with("topic_"), coder, ids = case, method = "reli") agree_tab(data_coded, starts_with("topic_"), coder, ids = case, method = "class", category = "catcontent")

what: Where do all the labels go?
title: High-Level Functions for Tabulating, Charting and Reporting Survey Data
text: One strongest package features labeling. know pain. Labels stored column attributes. Inspect current labels columns values codebook()-function: results table item names, item values, value names value labels. can set specific column labels providing named list items-parameter labs_apply(): Labels values inside column can adjusted providing named list values-parameter labs_apply(). addition, select columns value labels changed: conveniently manage labels dataset, save result codebook() Excel file, change labels manually copy Excel file, finally call labs_apply() revised codebook. aware data operations mutate() tidyverse loose labels way. case, store labels (codebook attribute data frame) operation restore afterwards:
code: codebook(data) data %>%   labs_apply(     items = list(       "cg_adoption_advantage_01" = "General advantages",       "cg_adoption_advantage_02" = "Financial advantages",       "cg_adoption_advantage_03" = "Work-related advantages",       "cg_adoption_advantage_04" = "More fun"     )   ) %>%    tab_metrics(starts_with("cg_adoption_advantage_")) data %>%   labs_apply(     cols = starts_with("cg_adoption"),       values = list(       "1" = "Strongly disagree",       "2" = "Disagree",       "3" = "Neutral",       "4" = "Agree",       "5" = "Strongly agree"     )    ) %>%    plot_metrics(starts_with("cg_adoption")) library(readxl) library(writexl)  # Save codebook to a file codes <- codebook(data) write_xlsx(codes,"codebook.xlsx")  # Load and apply a codebook from a file codes <- read_xlsx("codebook_revised.xlsx") data <- labs_apply(data, codes) data %>%   labs_store() %>%   mutate(sd_age = 2024 - sd_age) %>%    labs_restore() %>%       tab_metrics(sd_age)

text: prop: Calculating percentages cross tab requires careful selection base. can choose total, row column percentages. stacked bar charts, displaying row percentages instead total percentages gives direct visual comparison groups. ci: Add confidence intervals plot table outputs. index: Indexes (=mean multiple items) can added dataset using add_index() , using index-parameter, automatically included report functions. Cronbach’s alpha added table outputs. factors: Items can condensed factors using principal component analysis. add_factors() new columns added. factors-parameter report_metrics function automatically adds factor analysis outputs. clusters: Cases can grouped clustersusing kmeans cluster analysis. add_clusters() new column indicating cluster groups added. clusters-parameter report_metrics function automatically adds cluster analysis outputs. effect: sure whether differences statistical significant? One option look non overlapping confidence intervals. addition, effect option calculates effect sizes Cramer’s v R squared generates typical statistical tests Chi-squared tests t-tests. method: default, correlations calculated using Pearson’s R. can choose Spearman’s Rho methods-parameter. cooccurrence analysis categories (provide two variable sets report_counts()), can choose Cramer’s V (items compared items) NPMI (single item values compared). case, recommend also set tiles-parameter TRUE generating heatmap (default bar plots). Normalized pointwise mutual information helps spotting combinations rare (negative values) frequent (positive values) expected chance. can add “npmi” numbers parameter plot values tiles. adjust: Performing multiple significance tests inflates alpha error. Thus, p values need adjusted according number tests. default, false discovery rate controlled (fdr). can, example, choose Bonferroni-correction disable correction.

title: Agreement for multiple items — agree_tab
text: data tibble containing item measures, coders case IDs. cols tidy selection item variables (e.g. starts_with...) ratings. coders column holding coders methods compare. ids column case IDs. category classification performance indicators, category provided, macro statistics returned (along number categories output). Provide category get statistics category . values boolean (TRUE / FALSE) category provided, category always assumed "TRUE". method output metrics, one reliability classification. can abbreviate , e.g. reli class. labels TRUE (default) extracts labels attributes, see codebook. clean Prepare data data_clean. ... Placeholder allow calling method unused parameters report_counts.

title: Agreement for multiple items — agree_tab
text: volker tibble one row item. item name returned first column. reliability method, following columns returned: n: Number cases (case id counted ). Coders: Number coders. Categories: Number categories. Holsti: Percent agreement (accuracy). Krippendorff' Alpha: Chance-corrected reliability score. Kappa: Depending number coders either Cohen's Kappa (two coders) Fleiss' Kappa (coders). Gwet's AC1: Gwet's agreement coefficient. classification method, following columns returned: n: Number cases (case id counted ) Categories: Number categories Accuracy: Share correct classifications. Precision: Share true cases detected true cases. Recall: Share true cases detected true cases. F1: Harmonic mean precision recall.

title: Agreement for multiple items — agree_tab
text: Reliability: Compare codings two raters content analysis. Common reliability measures percent agreement (also known Holsti), Fleiss' Cohen's Kappa, Krippendorff's Alpha Gwets AC. Classification: Compare true predicted categories classification methods. Common performance metrics include accuracy, precision, recall F1.

title: Agreement for multiple items — agree_tab
code: library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: ‘dplyr’ #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:stats’: #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:base’: #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union library(volker)  data <- volker::chatgpt  # Prepare example data. # First, recode "x" to TRUE/FALSE for the first coder's sample. data_coder1 <- data |>   mutate(across(starts_with("cg_act_"), ~ ifelse(is.na(.), FALSE, TRUE))) %>%   mutate(coder = "coder one")  # Second, recode using a dictionary approach for the second coder's sample. data_coder2 <- data |>   mutate(across(starts_with("cg_act_"), ~ ifelse(is.na(.), FALSE, TRUE))) %>%   mutate(cg_act_write = grepl("write|text|translate", tolower(cg_activities))) %>%   mutate(coder="coder two")  data_coded <- bind_rows(   data_coder1,   data_coder2 )  # Reliability coefficients are strictly only appropriate for manual codings agree_tab(data_coded, cg_act_write,  coder, case, method = "reli") #>  #>  #> |item         |   n| Coders| Categories| Holsti| Krippendorff's Alpha| Kappa| Gwet's AC1| #> |:------------|---:|------:|----------:|------:|--------------------:|-----:|----------:| #> |cg_act_write | 101|      2|          2|    0.7|                  0.4|  0.42|       0.42| #>  #>  #> |item         | agree| coder one| coder two|  n|    p| #> |:------------|-----:|---------:|---------:|--:|----:| #> |cg_act_write |  TRUE|     FALSE|     FALSE| 42| 0.42| #> |cg_act_write |  TRUE|      TRUE|      TRUE| 29| 0.29| #> |cg_act_write | FALSE|     FALSE|      TRUE|  5| 0.05| #> |cg_act_write | FALSE|      TRUE|     FALSE| 25| 0.25|  # Better use classification performance indicators to compare the # dictionary approach with human coding agree_tab(data_coded, cg_act_write,  coder, case, method = "class") #>  #>  #> |item         |   n| Ground truth| Categories| Accuracy| Precision| Recall|   F1| #> |:------------|---:|------------:|----------:|--------:|---------:|------:|----:| #> |cg_act_write | 101|    coder one|       TRUE|      0.7|      0.85|   0.54| 0.66| #>  #>  #> |item         | agree| coder one| coder two|  n|    p| #> |:------------|-----:|---------:|---------:|--:|----:| #> |cg_act_write |  TRUE|     FALSE|     FALSE| 42| 0.42| #> |cg_act_write |  TRUE|      TRUE|      TRUE| 29| 0.29| #> |cg_act_write | FALSE|     FALSE|      TRUE|  5| 0.05| #> |cg_act_write | FALSE|      TRUE|     FALSE| 25| 0.25|

title: Prepare data originating from SoSci Survey or SPSS — data_clean_default
text: data Data frame remove.na.levels Remove residual values factor columns. Either character vector residual values TRUE use defaults VLKR_NA_LEVELS. can also define disable residual levels setting global option vlkr.na.levels (e.g. options(vlkr.na.levels=c("answered")) disable options(vlkr.na.levels=FALSE)). remove.na.numbers Remove residual values numeric columns. Either numeric vector residual values TRUE use defaults VLKR_NA_NUMBERS. can also define disable residual values setting global option vlkr.na.numbers (e.g. options(vlkr.na.numbers=c(-2,-9)) disable options(vlkr.na.numbers=FALSE)).

title: Calculate correlation and cooccurrence coefficients and test whether they are different from zero — .effect_correlations
text: data tibble. cols columns holding metric values. cross columns holding metric values correlate. method output metrics, pearson = Pearson's R, spearman = Spearman's rho, cramer = Cramer's V, npmi = Normalized Pointwise Mutual Information. reported R square value simply square Spearman's rho respective Pearson's r. category Calculating NPMI multiple items requires focus category. default, logical column types, TRUE values counted. column types, first category counted. Accepts character numeric values override default counting behavior. test Boolean, whether perform significance tests (default = TRUE). adjust Performing multiple significance tests inflates alpha error. Thus, p values need adjusted according number tests. Set method supported  stats::p.adjust, e.g. "fdr" (default) "bonferroni". Disable adjustment FALSE. labels TRUE (default) extracts labels attributes, see codebook.

title: Output test statistics and effect size for contingency tables — effect_counts_one_grouped
text: volker list two volker tibbles. first tibble contains npmi values combinations: n Number combination occurs. p_x Marginal share first category. p_y Marginal share second category. p_xy Share combination based combinations. ratio ratio p_xy (p_x * p_y). pmi Pointwise Mutual information, derived ratio. npmi Normalized Pointwise Mutual Information, derived pmi. second tibble contains effect sizes based cross table: Cramer's V: Effect size measuring association two variables. n: Number cases calculation based . Chi-squared: Chi-Squared test statistic. expected values 5 least one cell, exact Fisher test conducted. df: Degrees freedo chi-squared test. Empty exact Fisher test. p: p-value chi-squared test. stars: Significance stars based p-value (*, **, ***).

title: Output test statistics and effect size for contingency tables — effect_counts_one_grouped
text: Phi derived Chi squared value sqrt(fit$statistic / n). Cramer's V derived sqrt(phi / (min(dim(contingency)[1], dim(contingency)[2]) - 1)). Cramer's V set 1.0 diagonal contingency matrices, indicating perfect association.

code: library(volker)  # Set column labels using the items-parameter volker::chatgpt %>%   labs_apply(    items = list(      "cg_adoption_advantage_01" = "Allgemeine Vorteile",      "cg_adoption_advantage_02" = "Finanzielle Vorteile",      "cg_adoption_advantage_03" = "Vorteile bei der Arbeit",      "cg_adoption_advantage_04" = "Macht mehr Spaß"    )  ) %>%  tab_metrics(starts_with("cg_adoption_advantage_")) #>  #>  #> |Item                    | min| q1| median| q3| max| mean|  sd|  n| #> |:-----------------------|---:|--:|------:|--:|---:|----:|---:|--:| #> |Allgemeine Vorteile     |   1|  3|      4|  4|   5|  3.5| 1.0| 99| #> |Finanzielle Vorteile    |   1|  2|      3|  4|   5|  2.7| 1.2| 99| #> |Vorteile bei der Arbeit |   1|  3|      4|  4|   5|  3.6| 1.1| 99| #> |Macht mehr Spaß         |   1|  3|      4|  4|   5|  3.5| 1.0| 99| #>  #> n=99. 2 missing case(s) omitted. #>   # Set value labels using the values-parameter  volker::chatgpt %>%    labs_apply(      cols=starts_with("cg_adoption"),      values = list(        "1" = "Stimme überhaupt nicht zu",        "2" = "Stimme nicht zu",        "3" = "Unentschieden",        "4" = "Stimme zu",        "5" =  "Stimme voll und ganz zu"      )    ) %>%    plot_metrics(starts_with("cg_adoption"))  #> In the plot, 4 missing case(s) omitted.

title: Output a frequency plot — plot_counts
text: type frequency plot depends number selected columns: One categorical column: see plot_counts_one Multiple categorical columns: see plot_counts_items Cross tabulations: One categorical column one grouping column: see plot_counts_one_grouped Multiple categorical columns one grouping column: see plot_counts_items_grouped Two categorical column selections: see plot_counts_items_grouped_items (yet implemented) default, provide two column selections, second selection treated categorical. Setting metric-parameter TRUE call appropriate functions correlation analysis: One categorical column one metric column: see plot_counts_one_cor Multiple categorical columns one metric column: see plot_counts_items_cor Multiple categorical columns multiple metric columns: see plot_counts_items_cor_items (yet implemented) Parameters may passed count functions (see respective function help): ci: Add confidence intervals proportions. ordered: values cross column can nominal (0), ordered ascending (1), ordered descending (-1). colors adjusted accordingly. category: multiple categories column, can focus one categories simplify plots. default, column TRUE FALSE values, outputs focus TRUE category. prop: stacked bar charts, displaying row percentages instead total percentages gives direct visual comparison groups. limits: scale limits automatically guessed package functions (work progress). Use limits-parameter manually fix misleading graphs. title: plots usually get title derived column attributes column names. Set FALSE suppress title provide title choice character value. labels: Labels extracted column attributes. Set FALSE output bare column names values. numbers: Set numbers parameter “n” (frequency), “p” (percentage) c(“n”,“p”). prevent cluttering overlaps, numbers plotted bars larger 5%. width: comparing groups row column percentages, default, bar column width reflects number cases. can disable behavior setting width FALSE.

text: plot type depends number selected columns: One metric column: see plot_metrics_one Multiple metric columns: see plot_metrics_items Group comparisons: One metric column one grouping column: see plot_metrics_one_grouped Multiple metric columns one grouping column: see plot_metrics_items_grouped Multiple metric columns multiple grouping columns: see plot_metrics_items_grouped_items (yet implemented) default, provide two column selections, second selection treated categorical. Setting metric-parameter TRUE call appropriate functions correlation analysis: Two metric columns: see plot_metrics_one_cor Multiple metric columns one metric column : see plot_metrics_items_cor Two metric column selections: see plot_metrics_items_cor_items Parameters may passed metric functions (see respective function help): ci: Plot confidence intervals means correlation coefficients. box: Visualise distribution adding boxplots. log: scatter plots, can use logarithmic scale. aware, zero values omitted log value undefined. method: default, correlations calculated using Pearson’s R. can choose Spearman’s Rho methods-parameter. limits: scale limits automatically guessed package functions (work progress). Use limits-parameter manually fix misleading graphs. title: plots usually get title derived column attributes column names. Set FALSE suppress title provide title choice character value. labels: Labels extracted column attributes. Set FALSE output bare column names values. numbers: Controls whether display correlation coefficients plot.

text: data data frame. cols tidy column selection, e.g. single column (without quotes) multiple columns selected methods starts_with(). cross Optional, grouping column (without quotes). metric crossing variables, cross column parameter can contain categorical metric values. default, cross column selection treated categorical data. Setting agree "classification" adds classification performance indicators report (e.g. F1). need provide column selection values cols-parameter, provide column coders classification source cross-parameter, column containing unique case ids ids-parameter. index cols contain items metric scale (determined get_direction), index calculated using 'psych' package. Set FALSE suppress index generation. effect Whether report statistical tests effect sizes. See effect_counts parameters. numbers numbers print bars: "n" (frequency), "p" (percentage) . Set NULL remove numbers. title character providing heading TRUE (default) output heading. Classes tabset pills added. close Whether close last tab (default value TRUE) keep open. Keep open add custom tabs adding headers fifth level Markdown (e.g. ##### Method). clean Prepare data data_clean. ... Parameters passed plot_counts tab_counts effect_counts functions.

title: Create table and plot for metric variables — report_metrics
text: data data frame. cols tidy column selection, e.g. single column (without quotes) multiple columns selected methods starts_with(). cross Optional, grouping correlation column (without quotes). metric crossing variables, cross column parameter can contain categorical metric values. default, cross column selection treated categorical data. Set metric TRUE, treat metric calculate correlations. Alternatively, multivariable models (model parameter TRUE), provide metric column selection metric parameter categorical column selection cross parameter. ... Parameters passed plot_metrics tab_metrics effect_metrics functions. index cols contain items metric scale (determined get_direction), index calculated using 'psych' package. Set FALSE suppress index generation. factors number factors calculate. Set FALSE suppress factor analysis. Set TRUE output scree plot automatically choose number factors. cols contain items metric scale (determined get_direction), factors calculated using 'psych' package. See add_factors. clusters number clusters calculate. Cluster determined using kmeans scaling items. Set FALSE suppress cluster analysis. Set TRUE output scree plot automatically choose number clusters based elbow criterion. See add_clusters. model Set TRUE multivariable models. dependent variable must provided first parameter (cols). Independent categorical variables provided second parameter (cross), supports tidy column selections vectors multiple columns. Independent metric variables provided metric parameter tidy column selections vectors multiple columns. Interaction terms provided interactions parameter passed model functions. can get diagnostic plots setting diagnostics parameter TRUE. See model_metrics_tab,  model_metrics_plot  add_model options. effect Whether report statistical tests effect sizes. title: Output a frequency table — tab_counts
text: type frequency table depends number selected columns: One categorical column: see tab_counts_one Multiple categorical columns: see tab_counts_items Cross tabulations: One categorical column one grouping column: see tab_counts_one_grouped Multiple categorical columns one grouping column: see tab_counts_items_grouped Multiple categorical columns multiple grouping columns: see tab_counts_items_grouped_items (yet implemented) default, provide two column selections, second column treated categorical. Setting metric-parameter TRUE call appropriate functions correlation analysis: One categorical column one metric column: see tab_counts_one_cor Multiple categorical columns one metric column: see tab_counts_items_cor Multiple categorical columns multiple metric columns: tab_counts_items_cor_items (yet implemented) Parameters may passed specific count functions: ci: Add confidence intervals proportions. percent: Frequency tables show percentages default. Set FALSE get raw proportions. prop: cross tables can choose total, row column percentages. values: values output: n (frequency) p (percentage) (default). category: multiple categories column, can focus one categories simplify plots. default, column TRUE FALSE values, outputs focus TRUE category. labels: Labels extracted column attributes. Set FALSE output bare column names values.

Set metric TRUE, treat metric calculate correlations. clean Prepare data data_clean. ... parameters passed appropriate table function.

title: Define a default theme for volker plots — theme_vlkr
text: base_size Base font size. base_color Base font color. base_fill list fill color sets least one fill color set. Example: list(c("red"), c("red", "blue", "green")). set can contain different numbers colors. Depending number colors needed, set least number required colors used. first color always used simple bar charts. base_gradient color vector used creating gradient fill colors, e.g. stacked bar plots.

title: volker 3.2.0
text: CRAN release: 2025-10-10 Implemented linear modeling add_model() including effect sizes, standardised betas adjusted p values Implemented reliability calculation classification performance indicators agree_tab() Implemented cooccurrence analysis: report_counts() generates heatmaps (tiles-parameter) npmi values (method-parameter). Option keep missings possible setting options(vlkr.na.omit=FALSE) (pairwise instead listwise handling missings)

title: volker 3.1.0
text: CRAN release: 2025-04-05 SPSS labels now supported plot functions, width bars columns calculated data (similar mosaic plots) tables now row totals Improved error messages model_metrics_tab() model_metrics_plot() provide first draft lm analysis
